reviews.review_msg: Mr. Tront really cares about his students and is always willing to help. His notes are long but he gives clear tips on what's going to be on the exams and midterms. I had a great time with his projects and learned a ton about software engineering. The skills and knowledge he shared will definitely be a huge help in my future career.

He sends tons of ridiculously lengthy emails, and assignment instructions often exceed 10 pages. Some examples he provided were from 1990. The exams included questions based on his personal beliefs. This is a typical uni problem where students are forced to learn outdated methods. The project is not something you can put on your resume.

Our 276 professor's outdated methods made the class frustrating. We learned irrelevant concepts, printed thousands of lines of code, and spent most of our time on useless user manuals. The final project was a basic console-based bug report system that everyone did, with no room for creativity or modern practices. AVOID PLSS.

Would have recommended him if we were in the 90s but we're not. He is not updated and do not be fooled by his experience. Had to print out 10000's of lines of code for submission. If you're good at memorizing and writing verbatim, you'll do well. But honestly, you'd be a better software engineer if you dropped out and studied from YouTube.

His notes are disorganized. Teaches from notes that are 10 years old. Do not focus on the group project because at the end of the day you pass only if you pass the weighted average of the exams. You could get a 0 on all assignments and still pass. Save yourself. Do not make the same mistake I did. Worst prof I have ever taken a course with,

This instructor is proffessinal at talking so much. You can never get a concsice definite answer out of him. AND YES he did work to EA sometime in the 90s or 2000s but guess what WE ARE IN 2024.  He is incredibly confusing and disorganized. He has zero familiarity with modren day technology. I woulldn't recomment him to my enemy. Save yourself.

He has experience, but I think his experience is rather outdated. His lectures is mainly based on his experience and wordings, so you can't review from anything else (i.e. textbook) if you don't understand his lecture. I don't think his exams are hard, but his contents are confusing. However, he's pretty nice and sometimes funny.

He's really nice and passionate, but his exams are really painful (worth 60%). He makes us memorize, in exact words, HIS principle and HIS effort distribution, which is extremely useless and a waste of time to memorize. Most of the required readings are from the 1990s or early 2000s. I doubt they are more useful as compared to recent ones.

Pros: Caring, always happy to take questions, very approachable, genuinely super nice, loves interacting with students. Cons: forces you to memorize A LOT of unnecessary stuff for exams, submit assignments on paper. You have to physically print the codes and hand them in. (over 250 pages in total throughout the semester without exaggeration)
Incrediblely awfully bad

Russ has taught me more about software engineering then any other class I've taken. If you want to get a job, you'll enjoy this class. If you don't, then frankly you won't make it in the industry. HEAVY on group projects; difficulty will depend on your group members, but Russ does his best to help and become a manager if necessary.

I can get why his teaching style might not be everyones favourite but the "tangents" that he goes on are ALWAYS related to what we are learning at that time and from his previous work experience. Hella useful to hear in prep for co-op. He provides detailed slides and explicitly tells you what you have to memorize, and gives an in depth study guide.

Do not listen to the other reviews if you aspire to be a 10x engineer. You will have to work quite a bit, but you will learn a lot of relevant information about SWE. He responds to emails quickly, he will send emails to the entire class to answer common questions and to give hints about assignments/ midterms. He is extremely helpful. THE GOAT.

Extremely disorganized professor. Lecture notes have stories in them and you have to filter out half the thing he says in the class. He tends to get side tracked while giving his lectures. He spams emails left and right and ends up confusing us. Last minute emails for everything (assignments and exams).Do not, I repeat do not take courses with him.
Very bad experience disorganized save yourself

certified yapper. seems nice but seriously i think he just likes hearing himself talk because he says a lot without actually saying anything. havent learned anything. slides are insanely wordy and he gives unclear assignments
She is not very organized and assignments are very hard. Avoid if you can.
Is this course important? That is a YES YES! Is she teaching this course like it is important? That is a NO NO!

Basically reads off from slides and no additional explanation is given. Has a thick Indian accent that may be hard to understand for some people. Not very open to feedback when her performance is clearly poor and lacks coherence. However, it is still possible to score higher than a B in her class if you try hard enough. (MEMORIZE EVERY BIT)

In the beginning it seems hard and challenging, but after attending few week it is fine. The way to succeed is to pay attention to her notes and prepare for the quizzes and exams. She gives fair chance to improve and learn. She is a very focused on her work even then she talks about Super Bowl in the class. (which is awesome)
She makes you learn about the topics.

Her midterm is lack of organize. She breaks our reading break with a too much long INDIVIDUAL assignment. PS. This course is basically about TEAM WORK. For the first two weeks, we even didn't get notes. She is more like a TA not an instructor.

Unprepared, knowledgeable, stubborn and does not take criticism well. It took her a week to put together something resembling a course webpage. Terrible prof to have for such an important course. Avoid her at all costs.

So far, this instructor has been extremely unprepared. She doesn't have a website to keep students updated, she doesn't fill in notes, her explanations are unclear, the first assignment is a vague, understandable mess and her English is atrocious. The announcement of the first assignment, word for word says:  "It has ben uploaded".
Very strong accent that makes it difficult to understand new material in lectures. She also doesn't fill in the lecture slides, and seems very unprepared to teach in general

Extraordinarily difficult to understand. It's not her fault that her accent is bad and she has bad English, but it bothers me very very much, as it directly affects my education. Assignment specifications are impossible to understand, and she doesn't know how to explain things. Incredibly frustrating class.

clear lectures, knows what he is talking about, will get you interested in the material and the software space. make sure you are going for the employer project. he is accessible outisde of the lecture. will help you if you ask. the TAs are also good. You need to know the code for the Final and midterm and the theology for software developement.

(from Spring 2024) Bobby is very approachable and kind. Lectures are mostly conceptual, sometimes a little dense. He gives a few coding tutorials but you'll need to do some self-learning for the project. The lecture content and structure of the group project are extremely relevant to real-world software development. I really liked his curriculum.

Majority of the grade is based around one group project, this was clearly laid out and communicated. The project itself depends on how ambitious you want to be, need to find the goldilocks zone between being innovative enough and having the least amount of work without losing grades. Very nice prof overall and would recommend taking if you can.

He is good at teaching lectures, and the theory knowledge is interesting. But because 276 is a course that includes way too much workload, there are situations where he feels unhelpful. The feedback for projects are also very lacking, and it's confusing on how to do them better.
He is a good teacher, available and eager to assist students beyond regular office hours.
He is a nice prof I would say
Good prof, this class is very heavy in memorization and projects.

The main focus of the class is the project and is worth 40%. Bobby bases the project on web development, although the course material isn't explicitly about web development. He does however give a few tutorials during class and has a playlist on the basics of html, css, javascript and java spring which is enough to get started. Overall hes good.
Exams take a lot of content from the slides. He is almost always available for any questions, would take another class with him

Don't know why people said he's good. Just because he's nice?!
He expects students to know HTML, CSS, JavaScript, and PostgreSQL. I am trying to learn everything by myself from YouTube and other resources. If you don't know HTML, CSS, JavaScript, and PostgreSQL, learn them first, and then take his class. Otherwise, expect a very low grade.
Lecture notes are lacking, lectures are less informative and helpful than just reading the textbook.
Omg he doesnt teach anything. He bring such difficult midterm and final and expect us to know everything. Avoid him at all cost. Dont be fooled by the 4.3 rating here
Take CMPT 276 with anyone other than this guy. He makes you a terrible experience for a course that its fun and important.
One of the worst profs ever. Does nothing.

Professors like this (only had him for 276) should not be allowed to "teach". Although he can speak clearly, he expects students to know html,CSS, JavaScript, and PostGreSQL. having experience with non will grant you a C- average as thats the class average. Not to mention the countless people who drop this course.

I remember the average score he gives is just C- . and almost every thing about for project, you need to learn by your selves. and the test maybe test everything in his notes. no example for midterm and final

Bobby is an exceptional prof with excellent knowledge of the course material. As it is mentioned many times, his exams are unnecessarily difficult on arbitrary material, some briefly mentioned in lectures, others from course appendices. Be prepared for fairly difficult tests, but a great learning experience if you take any course with Bobby!

Bobby is a nice person, but I really don't like the way he teaches 276. The project and lecture content are wildly different, which means that everything you need for the project you'll be learning yourself. The project will eat up most of your time, but the final is worth 43%, and tests you on random trivia from his slides. Lots of memorization.

Nice person but his criteria is unclear and the grading is quite harsh. Exams are weighted heavily and really expect you to be able to apply the material. Tests you on things he expects you to have self learned (never mentioned in lecture).

This course is testing your ability to google. Prof is real nice but sadly does not teach much about assignment stuff. So if you are not very familiar with html, css and javascript then be prepared to spend hell lots of time on assignments.
the lectures are well organized and he gives interesting examples to real life software development processes. study his slides and you'll do fine on the midterm and finals.

The project is a hit or miss depending on your group. I unfortunately had a bad group which required me to complete the entire project practically by myself. The exams are based off the slides and you'll probably get away with not attending lectures.
Great prof, explains stuff well and is available outside of class too help. Would recommend.

Guy is based for hating this course, it is almost entirely useless information or obvious. The downside is that his exams are stuff he printed off ms word the night before, with options such as

a)
b)
c)
d)
e)
f)
a)
b)

Of course its the typical read from the textbook style that 9/10 of the profs have, but that isn't surprising to you, is it?

Hes not like any prof i have had before. He believes this is a bs course so his attitude towards teaching it isn't very good. He tried his best to teach us what he believes is actually useful though. He is entertaining but its hard to tell what we should be learning because he skips over half of his ppts. Easy class but hard to excel in it.

I loved his class, he makes it so fun  and it is the only class that I went home knowing what he taught in class, exams are fair, group project depends on your group, he gave everyone high grades, there are to much slides but you just need to go to class as he skips a lot and tells you what to focus on for the exams. One of the best classes!

This man is all jokes and no substance. Skips entire slides because it's 'redundant', and speaking with other 276 classes, he doesn't cover what they do. Exams are weighed heavily, much of it being mc's and he won't release the grade cut-offs. He was also quite negative towards his students.If you want edgy, pessimistic commentary on SE, go for it.

He says the term project's the most important part of the course, yet makes exams worth 70% of the grade. That wouldn't be a problem if they weren't just multiple choice gambles. Skips half the slides citing uselessness, leaving us underprepared for real world corporate/industry situations. Funny, cool guy but not the right course for him to teach.

Courseload and grading scheme was easy to achieve good scores. Exams were not too difficult, mostly containing MCQ. You can select your own team members for the group project and it was quite lenient. Lectures were not that useful but he was very funny and kept me engaged. Highly recommend if you need the grades and light workload.

Just show up to lectures. He explains the necessary topics well and filters through the garbage in the textbook slides. You'll have no problem passing this class with Pearce. He also makes lectures entertaining and discusses events in history that are very interesting to learn about.

Professor Pearce keeps things interesting. The class is pretty easy, with only multiple-choice finals reused from past exams. The group project is time-consuming but manageable. Unstuckstudy AI and ChatGPT were great study aids. Overall, a solid class choice.

I think he rolls a dice to determine your grade. It's very very easy to get at most B+ but impossible to do better except by sheer luck since the questions he asks on tests are so arbitrary and his personal opinions. The grade you get has nothing to do with how much effort you put in. Don't take if you need A or better

Dr. Pearce is a hunk of malignant magic. He's a social sorcerer and a complete troll. I love the guy for not taking life too seriously. The group project took so many hours, worth 20%... But the final is mcq reused from past exams (easy af). He's great for a course like this where all of the information in hot dog water. Pick good ppl for group.
only mcq in final

Steven Pearce is a very agile and friendly person.
There will never be biases coming into play in his exams either, so you won't have to worry about ambiguity!
I love his stories of exploring the world with his two best friends Jack and Daniel, and how he would love to research waterfalls in Beijing with Dr. Marx and Prof. Zedong.

Best prof!
If your actual performance in this course is a C-, you might even get an A by taking his class.

I really appreciate Dr. Steven Pearce that he made the online version of CMPT276 easier, particular when Anne Lavergne gave me a hard CMPT295 in the same term. But each coin has two sides, Dr. Steven Pearce did not teach a lot. I agree with most of other comments on him that "if you just want grade, take his course".

Steven may not be the best at teaching, but, he makes the class super easy! The average for the class was a B+ and the exams were not very difficult. On top of this, he's very funny and I actually enjoyed coming to lectures. The group project can be tricky if you get a poor team, but that is completely separate from the teaching material anyway.
GOOD professor, funny guy, not a tough grader.
This guy is not good if you want to gain knowledge but if you only needs grades then take this guy.

Steve is not a good lecturer, just reads slides of text to you, not even covering useful material, and complains about having to be there. Makes inappropriate jokes and is very unprofessional. Midterm and final are almost all multiple choice and almost half the questions are based on his opinions. Avoid.
Most fun course I ever took! Cant wait to take some other course with him!
Most disorganized prof ever! He's a great prof tho, really knows what he is talking about. Almost like a student as he procrastinates so much . Final was hard.
Amazingly funny and very knowledgeable. Great at explaining concepts and ideas and is very patient. Really helpful outside of class as well. An amazing teacher in every way.

Generally Ted is a very good professor however he's very disorganize. He procrastinates at the same level as a normal university student, so our group project was being written up while we're doing it. Also because of the time crunch a lot of the project was done by Ted and we wrote very little code. Great experience overall.

Ted seemed to always be behind schedule in terms of topics and assignments. This made the first few weeks fairly slow and lacking in content and the latter half was basically a rush to get things done on time.  To be fair, he tries his  best to answer any questions and is always open to feedback.

Actual fraud. I'm not even joking. Its the equivalent to taking an advanced calculus class only for the prof to go over addition and subtraction. He's also just a bad human being overall. 

I used to wonder why so many students say terrible things about him or talk behind his back but I now know why.
Janice and Robert! The doom duo! The world has never seen anything like these two!

The course involves an android app group project. Teammates are random. Prof is a nice guy but he's not clear about what he wants in each iteration of the project. His lectures are horrifically dry. Would highly suggest you take CMPT 213 with this course, because if you don't know Java you'll have to learn both Java and Android on your own.

I truly wonder why he chose to become a professor even though he doesn't like it. I learned absolutely nothing about software engineering. His criteria is ambiguous for the group project and he doesnt help out at all. Dont take the course with him, save your money from this fraud of a prof. Ive never disliked a prof until now.

Rob does not respect your money or time, in this course you're expected to write an entire android app with 3 other students while Rob shows you ted talks about how AI driven cars should run straight into a wall if there are pedestrians. He also will just leave half way through to China and not plan lectures around that. Seriously don't take.

For some reason this prof thought it was a good idea to not cover design patterns smh. Dry lectures. Limited help. 55% of grade is an android app, mostly free marks. If you have deadweight group for project, then GL. 20% for MC quizzes and 25% for MC/Short answer final exam which is pretty easy to get good grades on if you have good memorization.

I will now read to you the entire response given by Rob when a student had travel plans that interfered with a delayed exam:

Hi, Cole. You should postpone your flight so that you can take the exam.

This was the entire response. Worst person at SFU.

Complete scam. The course is based on an Android project and Rob teaches 0 Android development, so get ready to learn 100% on your own. Instead he teaches a load of useless unrelated garbage which you have to memorize for weekly quizzes and the final exam. He also left for vacation halfway through the semester. SFU give me my money back!!!

Rob is the least competent educator I have ever met. Materials are lazy, criteria is non-existent, he lacks any semblance of effort in his teaching. His content is ambiguous, contradictory, and tedious. Skipped about 30% of the course. Mid way through the semester, left for China, and was inaccessible. I could rant, but RMP has a 350 chars limit.

That class was a waste of money and time, did not learn anything important nor practical. Be aware of the android project, and Rob won't help at all. Barely responds to emails. He should be retired to be honest...

Prof is very unorganized. The project requirements were vague and marking was done very poorly. Additionally the project is very difficult due to the lack of guidance and you are expected to parse a textbook in order to mangle an android application together. Quizzes and tests are just pure memorization with no questions that test comprehension.

Rob took a vacation mid semester, and put a very low effort into creating lectures. There is no android programming taught yet you're expected to put together a fairly complicated application together. I do not recommend taking this course with Rob Cameron.

In lecture, he just talked about code ethics, security, software requirements and etc. And for the project, he just throws hes parabix project to you with no comments and no explanation to write. The only way you can know how to write the code is keep sending emails and ask him. By the way, he reply emails very slowly. The worst professor everse

He didn't give us any information about the final and didn't provide us with final percentages. His very quiet and slow lectures put me to sleep, of which are also mandatory because, quizzes. His project was boring and not up to date with new technology. Should retire tbh.

Nice guy, poor lectures. He basically just restates the slides and rambles. The full slides are posted before the lecture, so the only reason to show up is for the quizzes. Project was fair though. The marking was generous and his expectation for our work was realistic. He's still okay, you should definitely still take 276 if he's your prof.

This course is based on a huge group project, so your grade mostly depends on your and your groupmates' work. The project was very interesting but Dr. Cameron had a problem with timing, since we have never received all requirements on time. Quizzes were heavy but final was just a basic compilation of everything. Overall, he is good for the course.

No clear grading criteria is given... There is a team report and we weren't given a grading criteria for it. We weren't given about what would be on the final. Seems like a nice guy, but I want more progressive feedback. Final felt very easy but I got a lower mark than I expected.

Completely disorganized, the quiz questions are mc and are trick questions, not meant to test knowledge. The requirements for the project are never updated/organized and are scattered across multiple pages of the course website. Once he asked for a new requirement the day a project submission was due. AVOID
Incredibly vague project requirements and grading criterion and some of the most dull lectures I have ever attended makes me give this prof an F.

Saba is my personal GOAT of SFU. If you just ask questions and show up (and maybe carry your group project) it is SUUUUPER free. Midterms were graded pretty fairly, group project too.

Just be ready to do pop quizzes tbh.

Saba's lectures were kinda boring and sometimes difficult to follow. This class has a group project and that ofc depends massively on group RNG but is generally ok. There were also pop quizzes but if you showed up and just copied whatever she wrote during the discussion afterwards you got 100% on those. Overall ok-ish
Saba was great. She has pop quizzes based on lectures but you are pretty much guaranteed 100% on them if you just follow along in class.

Lectures were boring, I haven't learned a lot from the lectures. I only went in case there was a pop quiz. Aside from that, her course was structured well, although the grading scheme held a bit more emphasis on midterms and assignments rather than the group project that took up the majority of the time. Overall great prof and fun group project.

Saba's lectures felt dry and boring, I didn't learn much in this course. We had a group project, but it was mostly unrelated to the lecture material and we were forced to do everything on our own, including organizing in our groups. The midterms are just random questions from the slides, they are simple tests of memorization.
Come on you guys, you cant give Jane Mcdonald a 2 and give Saba anything less than a 5. She is chill, caring and she knows a lot. Shes great.
she has pop quiz, but they are just directly from the most recent lecture. Classes are engaging, fair exams. Can't complain.
10/10 would take classes with her again. Awesome human.
good prof. Caring, consider and knowledgeable. Fun lectures.

And also, be comfortable with Java. Why not? Java is heavily used for OOP in industry, and if you go to school just to be in your comfort zone, maybe dont do comp sci? If you have a good foundational knowledge of C++, you will understand that Java helps not reinvent the wheel, auto cleans garbage and focus on good coding practice, that's all..

I am a current 276 student w Saba F24, and she is knowledgeable, supportive, engaging, funny, accessible outside office, fantastic lectures, exams are highly correlated with what taught in class. The dude who said her lecture is dry PROBABLY NEVER SHOWED UP AT LECTURE AT ALL?. Anyways, I am grateful to have been her student. Learnt a lot so far!
Good prof

She makes us learn Java when she has very little Java knowledge. Unclear grading as TAs do not provide any feedback so they can arbitrarily deduct marks. Takes forever to release marks and also does not release midterms so will have no idea what went wrong.
Saba is a good instructor. She provides clear and constant instructions, and has good lectures.

She is the best prof I have ever had in my WHOLE life! Stronly recomand this prof. Saw some comments sayin shes bad, they are jokers. Super easy course and easy A+. Do not mind others comments just take this prof and you will get a exceptional good grade! What a gem!

She was very great! Everything was organized, and the lectures were not dry at all. There could be some pop quizzes so attendance is kind of mandatory. She was also helpful outside the class, and the grading was not tough at all. Overall, I enjoyed my semester with her. She definitely does not deserve 2.5. For me, she was 4.

She just added 2 assignments on the last 2 weeks of the semester, which is just ridiculous, when there are finals we need to study for. She did not release a grading scheme until halfway in the semester. The lectures, don't get me started, she does not add any useful information in class. Overall, this was poorly organized and I am dissatisfied.

Exams are marked very hard, the average for the second midterm was 50% before scale. Her lectures are terrible, very dry and you do not learn much but she has pop quizzes so you kinda need to to go. Overall, she is a horrible teacher and had a bad experience in this course.
disorganized and does pop quizzes but shes not the worst

Very solid prof. Background in Java or C/C++/C# will be an asset. Low work load and very open to extensions. Content is generally easy. Has consistently had group term projects, so group RNG will be a factor in experience. Even if she doesn't respond to your emails, she probably still read it so don't worry too much.

Saba is a young professor who has not mastered her craft yet, but she is very good at what she does, I recently took cmpt 276 with her and she was very good at explaining concepts. She was very easy to reach after lectures and was always willing to help with a positive attitude. 

I think saba is great, for 276 start your projects early though.

Saba is brilliant and amazing, although I wish she communicated with the class more ahead of time. She's understanding and the course material isn't that hard. This course's difficulty entirely depends on the group you are assigned, and unfortunately, if your group sucks then you'll have to deal with it. That's my only complaint.

I read the reviews before coming into this course and thought it would not be as bad, I was wrong. The course is in Java and she admitted that she has not used Java in several years. It feels she does not care about this course at all, do your money and time a favor by not taking this course with her.

Her notes are filled with fancy words and terrible examples that are unrelated to the assignments. Even she knows her lectures are terrible as she constantly asks the class for feedback with no response. On top of this she just tells you to make a game in Java, without any instruction on how to even code in Java, let alone how to make a game.

Saba unfortunately does not know how to teach. her slides are written with so much jargon they might as well be written in Spanish. She will ask the class questions about the slides she hasn't read yet and complain when they do not respond. Please take this course with another professor.

IF YOU WANT TO LEARN SOFTWARE ENGINEERING, do NOT take this class with Saba. Even if there is no other class. This class doesnt help for an actual job, nor do you learn anything besides history that makes you fall asleep. It is just a normal java class you can learn on your own in a few weeks. Also have fun trying to contact her, nearly impossible

What even was this class. Intro to software engineering was more of intro to disorganized java. I 100% recommend taking this class with ANY other prof. Bobby chan, Brian Fraser , > Saba. Saba is not meant to be a prof and that shows with based off other reviews. If you wanna be thrown tons of work at urself at random times, have fun. Else, drop it.

The most realistic review you will get is this one here: - She is very unorganized (doesnt decide the course grading until midway through the semester) - Nearly impossible to reach outside of office hours - Be aware of surprise assignments near final exam time, she threw 2 assignments at us after our final project - You dont learn much

Basically, what the others said, handed out 2 assignments that are due during the final exam period. no course grading scheme was available until halfway through the course. WILL NOT reply to your emails she is literally inaccessible outside of class. does not grade assignments on time. she is just very very disorganized. Avoid

(2.5/5) Disorganized class, grading scheme was given halfway through the semester, dropped 2 assignments 2 weeks before classes are done. Lectures are fine, not the worst. The project is a 2D maze game in Java, not a fan of the idea. Good luck with contacting her, won't respond to emails or canvas, go to her OH. Quizzes are memorization of slides

Boringgggggggg. 3 lectures in and I became snorlax. History of software > actual learning/doing of today software in this class. You want to code? Nope, not in this class you wont. You want an organized prof? Nope not in this class you wont. You want to become a software engineer? Nope not in this class you wont. Only good thing is the sleep.

If you do not know Java, then get ready to put extra work in learning it. The other section was taught by Brian and he goes over the basics for a few weeks while Saba jumps right into the materials of the project after week 1. There will be a massive group project. Many assignments. So if you arent good with Java; dont take this yet.

Great person, sometimes brings her cat to lecture too. However, the class was a complete mess, two assignments were never given out due to a lack of preparation. You must have Java experience! Quizzes were easy, the project was not very easy but it is hard to not get an A if you have something that works. No final, no midterm.

Professor Alimadadi is very nice and caring, she has good intentions but poor executions for many things in general. This class was quite a mess and I learned very little from her. The good thing is her quizzes are fair and easy. It is EXTREMELY difficult to reach her. If you email her, good luck, she probably won't reply to you.
She is a great professor.

She is a great and considerate person. But I'll say her teaching is mediocre at best. You basically have to self-learn Java if you have no experience in it as all assignments and the project are in Java but Java was not covered in class.

A promising new professor. She's a good lecturer with reasonable expectations and a fair course breakdown. Her 276 course did not have a final, which was nice for a content heavy course. There is a lot of material, so often she would race through lectures, speedily covering information rather than teaching it. Nonetheless, a solid choice for 276.

She is so hilarious. All her assignment documents are very ambiguous. She is not willing to help. In her class, she is speaking from the begin to the end but there is not a single useful sentence. SFU new instructors are worse for every year.

Literally every single CMPT class I attended at SFU so far uses C/C++ yet she assumed the students to understand Java already. Admittedly, there are a lot of similarities between Java and C/C++ but for the most of the assignments, Google was more useful than the teacher.

It was Prof Saba's first course teaching us, Since it was her first time, many things can be improved for sure. But there's one thing i can tell is that she is very caring for her students and we can really feel it. Decent amount of work and I learned a lot about coding my first game in java! Go to her office hour and she is extremely helpful!

Pros: Accessible and responsive; good feedback if you ask.   
Cons (group project): too open-ended; groups poorly balanced; prompt was not good relative to other offerings; lectures were not helpful; not enough guidance; vague requirements.
Cons (exams): No practice questions; difficult; heavily based on lecture material. 
Bad learning experience

Pretty good lectures. Accessible outside of class. I don't get why people are complaining about implementing an AI! All that was asked was a simple, reasonably logical one for a board game you make! 
Midterm and Final questions were stuff mentioned in lectures and slides. 
Issue was that the material is mostly memorization based. Be prepared.

Never done so bad in course exams. Very memorization based and MCQ heavy but that's not a good thing. Project deadlines were quite late, as in you pretty much had to do 70% of the project in 2 weeks for the second deadline. It asks for an AI (way hard for a 200 course) as well. Pray for good group members or you're botched.

Prof Wang is an accommodating, kind professor. It is certainly hard to make group projects fair, nevertheless, the project with my group was fun, and I enjoyed doing it. However, the exam's MC are certainly difficult, as there are not much practice questions, and the questions cover many topics, making the testing scope broad I think

Half of the course grade is on the project, which entails implementing AI in a 2nd year level course. If you find yourself with bad group members, you're done! It appears the professor doesn't address issues with unfavorable team assignments. It might be worth considering a different professor to save yourself some potential difficulties.

Parsa is the best cmpt prof I've had at SFU, he focused on teaching actual practical tools and concepts, on top of giving us actual projects that are designed to be added to your profile, he genuinely cares about his students and wants the best for them, I seriously recommend him, his exams are very fair for the topics taught as well.

By far one of the most organized, inspiring and positive profs I've ever had. Using AI is allowed (although you need to disclosure it) and he even taught us about prompt engineering. Picking groupmates that you like and get along with will be important. Start hte project early. Trust meee

Parsa is realistic and advocates to the use of AI as long as it benefits your learning. He very caring and truly wants all students to succeed, beyond the scope of the course itself. Lectures are consistently positive and engaging, but doesn't help much with exams. Pray for good group members as you will be working with them from the beginning.

Simply the GOATed prof. Lays everything out and describes everything that will be on tests (we also had access to a cheatsheet). Responds to slack messages immediately, and genuinely wants to help you. Provides a variety of resources and tools to help aid your learning, including custom NotebookLMs. I can't wait to take another course with him

I had heard a lot about 276 before, and after taking it, I can now say that as long as you put in the work, you will not be disappointed. I don't go to all lectures but w/ parsa's teaching style, class activities were a big motivator for me to go. I loved the project and peer testing. It was clear that he really cares for us, which is rare @ sfu

I've never written a review but this course/Parsa deserve it: 
1. Take the course w/ your friends or make new friends in the semester (for project)
2. There are a lot of in-class activities that might not make sense in the moment but they all came in handy for the project
3. Start the project ASAP 
4. Office hours are super helpful 
5. Stay ahead

Parsa was great and the types of assignments and projects you do in this class were really engaging and fun. Make sure you pick a good group for the main project though. One thing is that the midterm was quite tough and I didn't like how peer evaluations affected the final project mark (it will deduct marks UNLESS you get a perfect score of 100).

GOAT! I took 276 as my first course @ sfu (transfer student) and hands down, it was one of the best classes i've ever taken!! I loved how interactive the classes were and how fast parsa replied to  messages. Topics were also helpful with one being prompt engineering (ai was allowed in the course). Do yourself a favour & take a course with parsa

GREAT PROF. I would take any class as long as he is teaching. He teaches life skills, rather than just classroom stuff. I feel like, if you learn from him, it will help so much in life. 
I know why some people have rated him bad, the course in previous semesters were harder, but he has taken the feedback and improved. Love parsa.

One of the most caring profs I've had at SFU. I rarely attend lectures for my classes but Parsa's lecture activities were helpful and inspiring that made my 1.5hr commute worth it. I also found Parsa's office hours to be nice, esp wih career advice. The project was the highlight of the course for me
What can I even say? Parsa was by far the best professor I've ever had.
find a good group and you'll be set (or else, gg). i really enjoyed the in-class activities, but don't take it with a heavy course load (my group mate did and he struggled)

Taking 276 with Parsa was the reason I landed a co-op this summer. I got lucky with a pretty good group for the project and we had fun along the way. The labs and lectures really helped with the project.

The course is super structured and organized (we had all assignments & project deadlines on the first day of class). I found this very helpful as I planned my time around it & was able to avoid cramming. Parsa is super accessible on Slack (almost all my questions were replied to within less than 1 hour, even on weekends). Absolute GOAT!!!!
One of the most caring and inspiring profs I've ever had. Put in the effort and you will not be disappointed.

There's gonna be a lot of workload but Parsa and the teaching team help out in any way they can. Exams were easy enough, projects were fun to work on. Overall, this was a great course and learning with Parsa made it even more enjoyable

One of the best profs at sfu. Genuinely one of the best classes I've ever had. Assignments are good for learning, decent lectures and fair tests. He is also always looking on how to improve and make his course better(ex allowing ai for certain stuff, replacing midterm with final, bonus marks) all these were decisions made from student feedback.
one of the best profs you can get for 276. He puts effort into the course
I love you parsa
Midterm and final wasn't pleasant at all, like this course shouldnt be that bad,but the prof made the exams actually harder than it should be.

Parsa was a great professor, was very understanding and helped throughout the entire process of developing our own web app. Although the course is difficult with lots of work, Parsa gave lots of support and was very understanding. He also gave advice for beyond the course and was an engaging lecturer, if you can take 276 with him! You will learn!

Hands-down the most caring and organized prof. I went to Parsa mid semester about a problem i was facing and he was very understanding of my situation. I did not get the same support from any other prof that i had this semester. I also got some great advice from him for research and co-ops which helped me land a job for the summer
Class was very easy, people in these reviews just hating. Put in the work(which is very little) and you will do good. Fun prof and very organized class. Better than a majority of CS prof's at SFU.

I am writing this review because before I took this course, I was really scared after looking at the reviews.I am pretty sure Parsa is not teaching this course again, but this review is not about the course, Its about Parsa. He is a great Prof to have for anything. He is caring, and gives skills useful for lifetime. Its about putting in the effort.

This semester, he did a reverse classroom style.  Requires a lot of self studying for coding, but he teaches many skills needed for projects like CI/CD, SDLC, and project management.  Super engaging classes, but be ready to study a lot.  Also, group project requires high effort, feels like 2 classes instead of 1. (AI is allowed for coding)
Probably the most organize and well put together course i've taken at sfu. The peer testing session was by far my favourite, i don't think i ever been that excited to attend class

When he's the one marking an assignment (not the TAs), he has a habit of not reading through the full assignment submission and then takes off marks for things that were done properly, that he missed when reading your submission. Then when you email him about it he will ignore you.

Parsa's expectations from students to know everything in detail from so many readings, videos, lectures,  and other resources he posts for exams is out of line. I've definitely learned some new good and helpful stuff but his midterm was bad. As a prof, parsa puts in very little effort wrt what he expects. i dont like his grading criteria either

I've gained valuable industry skills like Git, SDLC, MVC, HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Figma React, & much more. Course is demanding, so I recommend taking only one or two other classes alongside it. Despite the workload, I'm grateful for the knowledge and feel prepared for co-op applications. Parsa & TA's are always available through slack & o hours.

Parsa is a good professor, even if many reviews say otherwise. Yeah...He gives alot work, with some of the marking distribution uneven. But he's passionate, cares about the class, is easily accessible, and very organized. Exams and midterms are easy and crammable in 1 day , lectures are skippable, and most time is spent on projects/assignments.

Even 50 Americans can't compare to how heavy the workload from this guy is. I'd rather have Gorlock the Destroyer sit on my face than go through this class again. It was a 3 credit course, but I put in more hours into this course than my other 4 courses combined. Never taking another course with him. He is a pretty good prof tho. im just weak ig.

This professor is absolutely ridiculous with the amount of work they assign. Every week there's a new assignment, and each one takes hours to finish. The assignments are way too long and overly complicated. If you don't want to spend all your time drowning in homework, don't take this professor.
Ridiculous professor, dont like his teaching and assigned ridiculous homework that we had no time to do.

Don't take with him, the lectures didn't even cover the topics in the exams. 
Wait for other prof if you wanna pass

I took parsa last semester and I will never be taking a class with him again. He assigns way to much work and theres not enough time to do it. A student literally pointed it out to him in class and the workload did not change one bit. Take this class with someone else if you value your time and sanity.
Theres way to many assignments, one lab literally took one week to do, that was just a lab now imagine the assignments they dont end. Please avoid!!!
Way to much work not enough time to do them, i would suggest not to take him!
Don't take it with him. workload is insane, way too much for one class. Assignments never end. Not worth the stress!!

I I strongly recommend avoiding this prof if you value your time and sanity. Workload in this class's absolutely overwhelming. Tons of assignments and excessive amount of homework, to the point where it felt impossible to keep up. Prof didn't even seem to care about the burden and there was very little to no support or flexibility

DON'T TAKE THIS COURSE WITH HIM!!!!!!!!
Too much workload and very less amount of time

Parsa's class wasn't the easiest walk in the park but i think it was work it. There is a lot of work to be done but parsa makes it easy to understand. It was the first course i've taken that openly let students use chatgpt which helped for harder topics. The timing of class (830am in surrey) wasn't ideal but oh well

Parsa cares about teaching. His syllabus covers lots of useful topics, and you'll apply them in the group project. The group assignments and project take a lot of time, and some sections, like testing, need some self-learning. Workload makes it not an easy course. For me, the content made it worth it. Take it with a friend for the group project.
Do yourself a favour and don't take this class with him.

Beware of the amount of work you'll get in this class. Especially for the group assignment, the TA's mark very harsh on them and we have no expectation of a clear grading criteria, TA's make up mistakes not even mentioned. Every assignment needs an AI disclosure form which seemed redundant, almost like he's forcing us to use A.I and own up to it.

i quite enjoyed this class. it taught me a lot about git and was a good excuse to make a project and a personal website (which i had meaning to make for quite some time). I did find the workload to be on the heavier side but the labs were very helpful. I also felt like parsa actually cared about our learning esp with the guest speakers we had

Parsa was an amazing prof who cared a lot about his students. The workload was heavy at times when labs/assignments/the project overlapped, but it was manageable. The course content is beneficial, and Parsa's teaching style fits well with the course as he shared his own experience. His Zoom lecture with SFU/UBC alumni was also a good experience.

The workload for this class is completely insane. Be prepared to spend 20-25 hours a week on this class (sometimes 30+). He'll have a major 40-hour assignment due on Weds and then another 15-hour assignment due Fri. I've talked to other students and they think he's deliberately assigning obscene amounts of work so we're forced to use AI to do it.

i loved Parsa's teaching style! He used examples from his jobs (like software dev, devops or proj manager) to teach. It was obvious that he has a passion for teaching, esp as he let us to use ChatGPT (although we had to report how we used it). The assignments and labs were very useful for the project. Parsa made the 8:30am class worth waking up for

Not sure what the negative reviewers are talking about, unlike any other prof I've had, Parsa actually cared about us. After the strike (class got cancelled for 3 weeks), he adjusted the number of assignments and listened to us. I do agree that having more time for the project would've been helpful but I don't blame him cause of the strike.

Parsa cares for and considers his students. He takes time to listen to feedback and make changes appropriately. He does give a lot of homework which is time-consuming and comprehensive, however, it's a good way to learn and you really do in his class. His lectures are entertaining and easy to follow.
we got lots of work (assignments, group project and tests) in short amount of time due to strike. he is very nice and approachable.

Parsa is a really great prof and he gave us lots of opportunities to get bonus marks as well. Sure the group project grading was a bit harsh and he could've provided more time to finish it but the overall class and project experience was great. The lectures were fun to attend with clear slides. Get ready to spend lots of time on assignments!

He's an okay prof. 6% of the grade was attendance which is nice. We did only get a couple weeks to make the final project website and it was graded very harshly. He assigned a lot of work with due dates around tests. Overall, if you do the work you can get a good grade in his class which is fair I guess.

He is fair and approachable. During office hours he was super helpful and explained things well. He does care about his students and overall a great professor. I do wish he replied faster to emails and messages. Nonetheless, I don't understand why some people gave him low reviews.

He was great overall, could've eased on the content given the course froze in place for 3 weeks due to strike. Marking scheme was clear, marked fairly and helped wherever he could. The app was graded very harshly and given that we were developing web apps for the first time that was quite unfair. I recommend him but be ready to spend loads of time.

Not sure what the other reviews were yapping about, but the grading was pretty generous (class average was 84%). I do agree that we should have gotten more than 3 weeks to make a fully working website with 2 APIs without any web development experience. But overall, his slides are solid and he is an alright prof. No finals but high workload.
had to make the project in 2 weeks and it was way better than the others and still got a B his grading makes no sense and he doesn't care about teaching properly

Do not take any class with this prof no matter what. He assigned too much work and graded it unfairly. His lectures are boring and useless for exams/assignments. He gave us barely 2-3 weeks for the final project and then graded it as if we're a company designing a website over the span of a year and not just 3-4 students.
Best professor I've had so far at SFU, I'm tempted to take classes I don't really care about just to get another class with him.

Brian's teaching is filled with passion and therefore highly motivating. His design of coursework is aimed at industry standards and helpful for students to kickstart an early career in computing science. Also, he takes care to suit the needs of all levels of students, and he sacrifices his private time outside of class to respond to questions

Brian Fraser is a God. Lively lectures, clear notes, fair quizzes, and you will learn a lot in the class. Will start you off with Java then ramp into android. By the end you will be fairly familiar with Android Programming. Project / assignments were a lot of a work, but fair. Would take a class with Brian again!

Learned a lot about git and how to make projects in a team. Assignments force you to learn Android and Java to do well in them, which is good. Only watched the first 2 weeks of lectures as content seemed a bit dry. Reviewed lecture slides 1-2 hours before quizzes and did fairly good in them. Didn't need to watch lectures as quizzes are open book.

Brian Fraser is quite literally one of the best profs at SFU. Also had him for CMPT 130 and he does a great job making the lectures engaging and the content absorbable. Projects were quite enjoyable and was very accessible for help and clarification on requirements whenever it was needed. You can just see the passion this man has when teaching.

Project-based course, and all 4 of them were pretty fun to implement. The group project difficulty depended on how good your teammates were, but Brian had measures in place to keep everything fair. Quizzes are doable if you just study the notes beforehand and attend lectures. TAs could have been better, one did not know how to use GitLab.

Class was sort of outdated. The android studio tutorials were from 2013 and many features have changed since than so it was confusing to implement such features. His quizzes were sort of difficult as if you dont go over the notes, you cant really do well. His assignment3 was more fun than the group project so Im not sure what happened there.

The group project was said to be resume worthy and something you would look forward to do. However; he has reused previous projects you can find online on github. Ruins the uniqueness of the class, His video tutorials on android are very very old and are unhelpful. His quizzes are confusing and hard. This class was for sure a let down, just boring.

This man is a god. He is so considerate and caring unlike most of his colleagues at SFU, and his YouTube videos are literally the best out there. Taking a class with him was an honour. you'll learn from his 276 class probably more than all the other level 2 cmpt courses combined.
One of the best choices you could make for a professor and course combination.
Really good professor
Lots of fill-in-the-blanks. Can ask anonymous questions on Piazza. Definitely enthusiastic. Class average is high. Grade will be scaled down.
Easy assignment/project and tough exam. You need to remember a lot of stuff to pass the exam. The curve is applied to this course. So pay more effort on the exam and you will be succeed.

Assignments/Projects are far too easy - class avg is 90%+. You are forced to watch his Youtube videos to complete them as well. He does not post complete notes online, so if you have life/work commitments it will be a large setback. Many of his exam questions require attendance in class because they will be lecture specific. Avoid if possible.

Ill say he is definitely the best prof in sfu. Extremely knowledgeable and willing to help. Assignments and project are very practical and useful in future. Take any course with him for real learning.
The best prof I have ever had in my life

He does his best to make material quite interesting during lectures. All the assignments are very practical as they are something you can actually use outside class. He is very accessible and cares a lot about his students. Be aware: heavy group projects, lectures are important as he tests something he only talks in lecture but are no in the notes.

Good guy, gives videos to help with assignments that are pretty easy for what you should know at this level. Only complaint is he scales up how much you need for a decent grade by quite a bit so be confident that you can get at least 80% if you want something that won't break your GPA. Also check you can run android studio it is a memory hog.

The project is alright and will be a good experience if you have a nice group. He talks a lot in class about his personal experiences, slides are very confusing and long. He reinforced the importance of reading the textbook but none of it helped. Exams were hard, not enough time to complete them so I made educated guesses. Marking was too specific

Unironically Goated Prof. Just do good on the project and you are golden. Exams are BS tho and require u to read way too much content. Instead, just pray to god and make educated guesses on every MC and Short answer.

96 question final and only 75 minutes to do is most definitely not enough time. None of the exams have practice questions to do so you have to just memorize 25 chapters of textbook info. TA also has a very questionable marking scheme that i do not understand. Should definitely try taking it with a diff prof, exam was brutal for alot of us

Worst prof Ive ever taken. Exams are extremely difficult with nothing to do with the lecture you learned, theres literally no way to prepare for his exams because they are so poorly made and confusing. Has no sympathy, and all he does is yap about useless stuff or himself throughout his lectures. Dry and dosnt care about students situation at all.

Not sure why there are bad comments about Dr Tsang.

He is a brilliant professor. He lectures are very clear, and he is a good speaker. 

He was super helpful with the project, and his overall knowledge of the field is very cool.
Take Brian Fraser he's a better prof. You're going to suffer in this man's class

The group project worth 50% is very good if u get a good group. 20% from interview assignment is probably the easiest 20% u will get in the 276 class. The final exam is nothing like what you do for the whole semester. The final is all about theory while the whole semester focus on s/w dev.

Prof Tsang helped me make a great decision - to drop out and learn everything myself. Provided no coding instruction whatsoever, and is completely out of touch with the state of contemporary software development. He helped me decide that SFU was a complete waste of my time and money. Now I work on personal projects and pursue certifications.

I did not enjoy Professor Tsang's course at all. He is not very nice to students. He sent an email to my class explaining what "action words" are in a question when we didn't answer his discussion question the way he wanted. This is insulting for students at this education level, especially when most students can speak English better than he can.

Harsh but not unfair. He takes deadlines very seriously and expects you to apply knowledge from other courses such as Java etc.. He also makes you work hard throughout the semester and gives a pretty tough final with 80+ MCQs. If you participate in class, and work hard, that'll guarantee you a decent final grade.

I don't think he was absolutely terrible since I did learn a lot from this class. It's just the nature of CMPT 276 that most of the learning comes from the group project. I'm writing this review straight off the final and about half of the material on the final he never covered in his lectures so... there's that. Don't think he cares too.

Awful, boring lectures, Tsang does not explain grading criteria clearly and also doesnt really teach anything, the majority of the course is a group project in which you need to teach yourself everything. Felt like a waste of a course. Avoid.
The assignments and lectures are not related at all. He doesn't teach anything useful that you need for the group project worth 50%.

After taking a class with Dr. Tsang I decided to drop out - realized I was wasting my money paying for classes like this and then ending up self-studying anyway due to poor teaching from those without industry experience/success. Complete waste of time taking this class - everything you will learn is self taught. The man is completely out of touch.
one of the worst professor in BC. That's all you need to know.

In his lecture, you get 40% time just literally read out the slides, 30% time for terrible jokes, 5% for skipping 95% of the slides, and the last 25% talking about how good he is. AVOID, or regret like me.

The prof gives the most boring and longest lectures ever. He reads off slides taken from a textbook and is very unorganized. He's a hypocrite because he grades you on things like pronunciation and enthusiasm both of which he clearly lacks. Also he can not answer a single programming related question. He only knows theories memorized from the text.

Herbert overall was a good prof. He had an enjoyable personality and made a 3 hour lecture bearable. He could work on making his assignments more clear and his communication outside of class but he makes up for his lack of communication by answering questions during class. He also had some insightful guests in his lectures which was helpful.

Someone needs to tell this professor that things are easier said than done. No matter the difficulty of the task given, he always makes it seem like it's simple and straight-forward. He won't give you any guidance on your tasks. Whenever something from his end requires extra work to do, he makes it a big deal. This prof is lazy and uncompassionate.

Forces you to sign a consent form to give away all your privacy rights. "I agree that all such audio recordings, including any reproductions thereof and all digital files,.. I waive all claims to compensation based on the use of my recordings by Dr. Tsang. I also waive any right to inspect or approve the audio recording after my interview."

He has straight rules (e.g., deadlines). If you follow them, you are OK. Overall, I think he is fair. The project was tough since it forces you to think of an idea, which is out of my comfort zone. I learned a lot, more than in other courses.

It's one thing to be a mean person, and another to be bad at your job. Dr. Tsang is both, unfortunately. Besides belittling his students and having a condescending attitude, he makes irrelevant and arbitrary decisions with which to deduct marks and then blames students for not addressing these issues. I have never once had an instructor like him.

This guy does not consider technical problems as an issue and was not aware of prerequisite knowledge students had before making us learn a new language and code an entire app in a few weeks. We submitted an assigning but due to a system problem, he gave us a 0, when we had proof of the technical issue. Had to cram the textbook for the exam
Are there any options for negative ratings? I think 1 is still too much for this class. MUST AVOID!!

Really bad class. Course material does not have anything to do with the required semester project which takes all of your time. Makes it really difficult to manage learning the course material and focus on making a project at the same time.

AVOID AT ALL COSTS! Stay waitlisted for a different prof, take it next semester, transfer schools, do whatever it takes to avoid him. If you're stubborn enough to ignore this warning, then the best word of advice I can give is to do the exact opposite of whatever he says. Start coding early and don't bother emailing him because he rarely replies.

Simon Fraser is harming the future careers of students by having such an incompetent, egotistical and out of touch instructor. Doesn't teach and boasts about his accomplishments all semester. This class was a complete waste of money, and SFU doesn't let even you evaluate Tsang's performance - not that he'd take advice or ever admit fault. REFUND!!!

Taking his lecture is depicting the current situation in the world. When you are taking his class, you will know how wonderful your life was before taking his class. No free time, have to read 1000+ slides and have to learn all by yourself. We should rather pay Youtube for the tuitions.

Think of it this way. The ONLY course material you're provided with is lecture slides and videos which don't include even a line of code. Think of the course project as a personal project with a group where you're not provided anything relevent from the course and you'll be graded on it very tough. I've never experienced anything like this.

As a third year student, this professor is the worst prof I've ever taken. He expects you to create an app in less than a week without having taught you a line of code. Lectures are useless because they're too fast and you won't have any time to take notes or absorb information. He sees his students as employees, which is an awful thing. Fire him.

If your only option is to take this class with Tsang, don't. He doesn't understand how to teach and provides no learning resources. Discouraged coding for the first 2 months in a course where many students had never used Java. Everything we learned in this class was self taught - google + stackoverflow. Avoid at all costs, don't waste your money!
man this guy is really rude and would not recommend if someone is looking to enjoy this class... rest of the comments are true to atleast some degree

Avoid at all costs. We were given a group project and expected to learn a vast variety of coding techniques and software without any direction. After asking multiple times, he provided no resources. I have emailed SFU and I'm in contact with their QA team about removing this guy from teaching. I actually am painful in the chest from the stress.

Terrible. Poorly organized, awful lectures with no hands-on development. Mistakes made in release forms and specifications. Expects 3 assignments to be handed in within the same week, and a first app version within this same week after telling us not to code for 2 months. Completely out of touch with the student experience. Avoid at all costs.

Has to be the worst CS professors at SFU. You will learn absolutely nothing of consequence from his lectures. You will be expected to learn how to develop a fully-fledged Android application from scratch and with absolutely zero guidance, in a single week. He assumes full proficiency in software engineering in a class that's supposed it teach it.

Absolutely terrible. Herbert himself is a nice sociable person but he is not a good instructor. He's very unorganized and has unrealistic expectations. We were given a week to self-learn Java and make an app. There was 0 talk of any sort of coding during the semester. Just 3 hour long lectures about the proccess of software development.
This guy cannot teach to save his life. Please remove him from SFU for the sake of future computer science students.

Believe the other reviews, this guy is absolutely terrible. His group project, which is worth 53% of your grade, is on a topic that a second or third year student would have never been taught. He consistently takes marks off for things not asked for, and when students question him, he flat out denies questioning and forces students to back down.
Heavy project based class, if you get a bad group then you're screwed... Midterm and final were challenging. Not very respectful to student opinion, old fashioned

His tests are not easy at all! Lots of times he straight up gives 0's for questions that could be out of 12 - 15. The group assignment is very iffy as well, as long as you get a good group you will be fine, but if you have bad luck , you may be looking at having to retake this class!

Worst professor I have ever had. Massive amount of disorganized slides to sift through. Almost irrational when grading, takes marks off for things that weren't asked for. Students required to learn everything practical by themselves. Exam questions can be poorly worded and the "correct" answer is the subjective opinion of the prof.

Working on a project with a team is nice, but it just isn't worth it since you legit have to memorize 900 slides of disorganized material for the mid term and 1600 slides for the final. This is more material than my other 4 classes combined. So if you don't want to be stuck memorizing thousands of slides, avoid at all costs.

Assignments require external knowledge which is never provided in class. You have to learn application development entirely on your own. Clear disconnect between the teacher and students extremely condescending towards students. He does not care about the students. Avoid at all costs.
Good class, bad prof. Avoid when possible.
Her class are very fair and very doable to get a good grade. She is a sweet lady, but don't let it fool you because her quiz and exam are not easy. Make sure you study all of her notes very well.
Super nice and a lovely prof. Her lectures are a bit stale, but she teaches with enthusiasm. Would not mind if she taught all my courses.
Jack is really and actually cares about the course and helping students

So much of the material in 276 could be quite the boring grind, but if you take this class with Jack Thomas you're guaranteed a fun time. Not only are the lectures entertaining, but he will actually give you some solid advice from his own experiences. All around great guy, and fantastic prof.

Hands down the best professor I've ever got at SFU. He is an amazing teacher and is caring and diligent with his students. He will tell you the truth about the Tech-Industry and what goes in the back. He is a real gem.

Jack is really good at helping students understand the importance of the material without being boring. He also offers 'real talk' about what it's actually like to work in the field that you might not get out of other instructors. The assignments were gentle enough to prepare you for the group project in Android Studio. Video tutorials are provided

Jack is an amazing Prof. he gives people the opportunity to score more in Assignments which are already pretty easy. His Midterm is also pretty easy most of the questions are application-based, so just go through the slides thoroughly before the exam. Highly Recommended!!!!

He is an encouraging and understanding instructor. He seems to genuinely care for students and makes the lectures fun with various efforts. He tries to offer anything he could for students to learn in a better environment, which is uncommon. He is a good person or at least a great instructor. Definitely take a course with him!

Jack is a really great prof. Unlike many other profs at the school he's a recent graduate so he is much more relatable from a student perspective. 276 has very boring lecture material but Jack kept it pretty interesting. Really enjoyed the class.
10/10 prof, he really wants everyone toe succeed and do well. The material has some dry bits but Jack makes the class fun and engaging!

Probably my favourite cmpt prof so far! Super nice and funny, cares about his students a lot. Assignments and project were very fair; not super difficult. Midterm was long, but he compensated and bumped up marks. Final was very fair. Show up to lectures, or at least watch the recordings and you'll be good to go!

Lectures were fun with a few memes in some slides. Assignments were simple to do, but the group projects were a lot more time consuming and difficult. Lectures were focused on theory while assignments is through videos or own research. Midterm was lengthy but final was good. Discord office hours were nice too!

For his first time teaching, Dr. Thomas did a good job. His lectures tended to be a little on the tangential side. I really appreciated the different perspectives of software engineering he offered. The project was a lot of fun and a good introduction to software engineering.

I quite like his style for a not-so-technical course like 276. He chats and jokes a lot but still explain the concepts quite clear. My only complaint is he doesn't talk much about Java or Android but the assignment and project are all about them, but I guess that's not completely his problem
